post_info.post_title: Dose Religion Belong on This List?

Hey now, UFOs are real... assuming they are alien spacecrafts is the problem.
 
 I don't know that all religion fits into that list, but the ones that invoke the supernatural do.

acupuncture is no BS.

 
 Why don't you think acupuncture belongs on the list? Sounds like you have some personal experience with it.

acupuncture is no BS.

 
 have to agree with that, I had some acupuncture a few years ago for some back problems, man that XXXX worked wonders .

I'm not sure what the common factor is supposed to be on that list, some of them work, some of them don't. There are plenty of herbal remedies that are highly effective; St. John's Wort, for example, acanacia, willow bark, digitalis (those are what I can think of off the top of my head).
 
 Chiropracty is a bit more debatable, needs more research, likewise acupuncture.
 
 Astrology is fairly transparently XXXXXXXX, at least as far as the idea that you can predict the fate of individuals based upon the movements of the stars goes.
 
 The rest of the list can be pretty much divided into those three groups, if I could be bothered.

I'm not sure what the common factor is supposed to be on that list

 They are all supported by anecdotal evidence.
I thought Voodoo and Witchcraft are religions.

They are all supported by anecdotal evidence.

 
 A lot of herbal remedies are supported by double blind placebo controlled studies, and some studies seem to suggest that acupuncture outperforms random insertion of needles. Astrology is provably inaccurate in its specific predictions. There is a big difference between testably false and unprovable.

I'm not sure what the common factor is supposed to be on that list, some of them work, some of them don't. There are plenty of herbal remedies that are highly effective; St. John's Wort, for example, acanacia, willow bark, digitalis (those are what I can think of off the top of my head).
 
 Chiropracty is a bit more debatable, needs more research, likewise acupuncture.

 
 True, although I think I heard my Mom say that echinacea has been proven to not work. But you're right, sometimes herbal stuff works.
 
 Acci:
 I don't have a personal experience with acupuncture, but the medicinal logic is sound. Also, the results are observable and the process, testable. Science has backed up the fact that acupuncture works.

Science has backed up the fact that acupuncture works.

 Do you have any references I would like to read more about that.

A lot of herbal remedies are supported by double blind placebo controlled studies, and some studies seem to suggest that acupuncture outperforms random insertion of needles. Astrology is provably inaccurate in its specific predictions. There is a big difference between testably false and unprovable.

 I agree some "herbal remedies" have been tested and are effective medicine but most are not.

I agree some "herbal remedies" have been tested and are effective medicine but most are not.

 
 Couldn't say for certain but I think most of the herbal remedies sold in pharmacies here have been tested. The problem is defining what you mean by a herbal remedy.

Couldn't say for certain but I think most of the herbal remedies sold in pharmacies here have been tested. The problem is defining what you mean by a herbal remedy.

 No they are not, the FDA does not require testing of homeopathic or herbal "medications".

No they are not, the FDA does not require testing of homeopathic or herbal "medications".

 
 1. I don't live in the US, so the FDA is irrelevant to my statement.
 2. Just because they don't have to be doesn't mean they haven't. Note I said most.
 3. Let's not forget that there are plenty of conventional "medicines" that don't stand up to scrutiny, like over the counter cough medicines.
 4. Conflating homeopathic and herbal remedies is dishonest and inaccurate. Homeopathy is based on demonstrably untrue claims. The claims for herbal remedies need to be assessed on a case by case basis.
 EDIT: this (rather large) booklet from the NIH in the US contains information about commonly used herbs and the research supporting their use:
 http://nccam.nih.gov/health/NIH_Herbs_at_a_Glance.pdf

Do you have any references I would like to read more about that.

 
 There's a Google for that.

There's a Google for that.

 
 All I can find is stuff like this.
 
 
The evidence for acupuncture's effectiveness for anything but the relief of some types of pain and nausea has not been established.[8][9][10][11][12] In the case of nausea, systematic reviews have concluded that acupuncture is no more effective than nonpenetrating stimulation of one point to reduce some types of nausea.[13] Although evidence exists for a very small and short-lived effect on some types of pain, several review articles discussing the effectiveness of acupuncture have concluded it is a placebo effect.

1. I don't live in the US, so the FDA is irrelevant to my statement.
 2. Just because they don't have to be doesn't mean they haven't. Note I said most.
 3. Let's not forget that there are plenty of conventional "medicines" that don't stand up to scrutiny, like over the counter cough medicines.
 4. Conflating homeopathic and herbal remedies is dishonest and inaccurate. Homeopathy is based on demonstrably untrue claims. The claims for herbal remedies need to be assessed on a case by case basis.
 EDIT: this (rather large) booklet from the NIH in the US contains information about commonly used herbs and the research supporting their use:
 http://nccam.nih.gov/health/NIH_Herbs_at_a_Glance.pdf

 I agree that some herbal remedies are effective medicine but didn't I all ready say that?
 
 Would like me to remove herbal remedies from the list?
 
 Judging from your reaction I would say that where you live has the same sort of rules as in the US so I don't see your point.

have to agree with that, I had some acupuncture a few years ago for some back problems, man that XXXX worked wonders .

 
 Placebo effect.

Placebo effect.

 
 I don't know if it was or not, all I know is that it worked. Although I didn't have traditional Acupuncture, Mine was done at A veterans hospital with electric current needles, it felt kind of the same as a TENS unit.. not painful but uncomfortable . Took a total of 6 sessions before I noticed a difference, after about 10 sessions the pain had been reduced by 50% or more. Then they put me on Pain Medications and stopped the Treatments. I doubt it was a Placebo Effect but I can't say for sure it was or not.

From the wiki on acupuncture:
 
 
The evidence for acupuncture's effectiveness for anything but the relief of some types of pain and nausea has not been established.[8][9][10][11][12] In the case of nausea, systematic reviews have concluded that acupuncture is no more effective than nonpenetrating stimulation of one point to reduce some types of nausea.[13] Although evidence exists for a very small and short-lived effect on some types of pain, several review articles discussing the effectiveness of acupuncture have concluded it is a placebo effect.[9][14][15] A 2011 review of review articles concluded that, except for neck pain, acupuncture was of doubtful efficacy in the treatment of pain and accompanied by small but serious risks and adverse effects including death, particularly when performed by untrained practitioners.[12] There is general agreement that acupuncture is safe when administered by well-trained practitioners using sterile needles.[16][17][18][19]
 
 Evidence for the treatment of other conditions is equivocal.[20] There is no anatomical or scientific evidence for the existence of qi or meridians, concepts central to acupuncture.[21][16][22][11][23]

 
 It also says that because of the invasive nature of acupuncture, it's difficult to really have double blind studies to be able to test it against placebo.
 
 And it might help against some stuff like soreness, but there's no way it is effective in preventing and fighting diseases or curing infertility...
yes, religion should be on this list. after all you already have witchcraft, voodoo and faith healing up there...

Cant see Deism on the list...would that be a ' religion' even though it sees a creator without a revealed religion.
 How about the delusion that the universe ' sees' itself through us.
 Lets call it Sagan XXXXXXXXism
